âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good challenge for the clash !

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: It bring's more fun in this grey world!

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good challenge for clash. Keep it up!

- Is Line 1 of the input necessary.  We are just scanning a line for space separated numbers.  We get the count from that.  I guess it helps a little since we can assume we scanned N integers but we can easily get that ourselves.  I didn't use N in my solution and neither did you.
- The code was easily created to solve this in the time allowed.
- Test cases all seem to provide coverage of the problem.
- My only concern is that there may be other clashes very similar to this.

Input section
* Please change "1st Line" to "Line 1" for consistency.
* If you are using [[N]] as the variable name, please change line 1 as:
<<Line 1:>> An integer [[N]] for the count of numbers
* In the description to "Next N Lines", please mention that the numbers are all integers.

Constraints section / Stub generator
* Suggest to reverse the direction of the first constraint (most people write the lower bound first), i.e.
1 â‰¤ N â‰¤ 1000
* Variable names should be consistent throughout the clash.
  â€¢ Suggest to use N instead of maximumPossibleFrequency in stub generator.
  â€¢ Suggest to use [[number]] instead of [[integer]] in Constraints section.

Thanks.

Thanks a lot 5DN1L for the first and detailed check on the contribution.

I appreciate your inputs, and have tried to address all of your indicated points. If you may leave a vote as well (upvote or downvote, as you see the problem), it shall help with realizing the apt score of the proposed problem as well. 

Thanks as always for providing well-directed suggestions to such contributions.

I see that you have raised valid concerns here. Thanks for your inputs.

- Line 1 is good to have for languages like C/C++ where knowing the expected count of inputs makes it definite to take that number of inputs through a loop. Yes, it is unnecessary for most modern languages like Python that can just input().split() to capture all of the space-separated array in line 2.
- Yes, I wanted to have a simple clash proposal that is beginner-friendly, so is solvable in under 5 mins. (A checklist point for clash approvers)
- I've tried to keep strong and variety of cases, and these big cases were generated with random() function of Python (with some constant multiplier to keep uniform gaps), so hopefully are a good fit. Improvements are welcome for all cases. I hope I've got this correctly.
- Yes, agreed. But maybe this one varies in testcases and somewhat on the expected output. And as per Clash of Code proposal of community guidelines https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/contribution-guidelines (see point 5 under General Guidelines), repetitions are relieved for CoCs, so maybe you may let this one go live to get picked for some clash with much lesser chances expected for a similar clash to immediately lead or follow.

These are my opinions for your points. Please use them for making you call now, and drop your vote if haven't already.
Thanks for your approval. I am glad that you've found this problem as ready for a clash. â˜º

Thanks for the approval. ðŸ˜ƒ
Didn't get the comment fully though. Please do add if there's anything specified in it.

Thanks a lot for this concluding Approval. 
Happy Clashing on it now ðŸ˜Š
